author: alexssd7fp
content: How fast the post merge sync is compared to PoW/snap sync?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: About the same time (we're still doing a bunch of benchmarks, but so far it looks like nothing changes)

author: alexssd7fp
content: How do you achieve that given the sync becomes much more complicated w/ beacon chain docked?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
It does not (it actually becomes easier)
The beacon node will give us a (fairly) recent header. We will reverse header sync with that (download the header chain from this down to genesis), then we download the blocks and the state at the recent header. If the beacon chain advances and gives us another header, we will integrate it into our sync. The big time wastes are in downloading the blocks and the state, which are the same pre and post merge

author: pietjepuk
content: It's just about postponing validation of the execution payload afaik, while the EL client catches up.

author: pietjepuk
content: It's similar to validating PoW proofs and headers without validating the transaction payload I guess, but then in a PoS world.

author: pietjepuk
content:
I don't think it's necessary to have a synced up beacon chain (you can be behind). Similar to snap/fast sync for the EL side, there is "checkpoint sync" for CL clients to quickly sync to a trusted point (which takes a minute or two). Then they will in the background backfill history, while staying in sync with the network. 
Contrary to snap sync though, you have to _provide_ this trusted point yourself (e.g. a link to a REST endpoint, or a file you got from a friend).
